section.title: Location-Speakers
section.para: Varieties and subdialects of Agaw (or Central) Cushitic language Kemant (Qimant) are spoken mainly in the Northwest Amhara region, north of Lake Tana. The number of actual speakers of Kemant is much smaller that the number of individuals who identify themselves as ethnically Kemant

biblioset.title: Bulletin of the School of African and Asian Studies

section.title: kemant Paradigm Lexemes
section.para:
The following lexical items are used in the verbal paradigms
lemma gloss properties
fäy- go conjuctive=fay, pos=verb
iw- give conjuctive=conj4, pos=verb
was- hear conjuctive=was, pos=verb
xʷ- eat conjuctive=conj2, pos=verb

section.title: Morphosyntactic Properties
section.para: Kemant paradigms employ the following property-value dimenstions

listitem.para: case: only marginally considered here. To be taken up in more detail when nominal morphology is added.
base: frequently in -∅ or -a. NB, not the object case in Agaw!
proClass: covers a number of functions
proSet: In the independent pronoun setA is used in general for noun-phrase heads, setB typically for subordinates such as possessives. Both however can occur with case markers (Appleyard1975, p. 20).

tam: Kemant has six main-clause tam values (imperfective, perfective, comound perfect, jussive, jussive2, and imperative), and seven subordinate-clause tam values. A number of the subordinate clause values are give formal rather than functional-semantic labels (a-, e-, n-subordinate), and are only partially glossed or described; all occur in affirmative and negative, except where noted. (Note that Appleyard's material did not allow complete documentation of all the subordinate-clause properties.)
perfectiveComp: compound perfect. "I have heard". Compound of a subordinate form of lexical verb, plusimperfective affirmative3 of wan- 'be'. Does not have negative distinct from perfective negative.
relativeSubject: the antecedent is subject of its clause
relativeOblique: the antecedent is not subject of its clause
genHeadRel: the number property of the head noun in the relative oblique paradigm
numHeadRel: the gender property of the head noun in the relative oblique paradigm
vSubjSet: In the verb the distribution of the two sets seems to be morphophonemically conditioned (Appleyard1975, p. 30).
pdgmType: a "meta-property" to distinguish some form displays which are not strictly speaking paradigms

section.title: Attested Archive Paradigms
section.para: The following two tables give the feature-value combinations of the paradigms wich are actually documented in the archive. The first simply lists the shared property=value pairs for each paradigm, and then the variable property=value-list (comma separated). The second listing gives a spreadsheet-like row-by-column enumeration for the properties which are common to each paradigm; this eventually should be user-sortable to facilitate the comparative study of the paradigms. The second simply lists the common property=value pairs for each paradigm, and then the variable property=value-list (comma separated). The abbreviation "PNG" in the paradigm variable-value lists stands for: [gender:f,m,⊤; number:pl,sg; person:p1,p2,p3] -- i.e., the PNG combinations normal with finite tam-forms.Clicking on the paradigmLabel will yield a display of the paradigm in question [either by link to hard-coded term cluster, or canned SPARQL query].

table.caption: Table 1: Prop:Val List of Default Paradigms
